column4: guys, question, if I'm going to partition my HD to dual boot with WinXP, with a root ubuntu partition and a Ext3 partition for /home and shared date, how big should the root ubuntu partition be?
(and also a partition for windows, of course)
- whole system will install in under 5 GB - but, if you plan on installing lots of libraries (KDE stuff, developer tools) I'd make it 10 - 15 GB to be safe.
- you should be sage with 12 GB.  Also, I find it adventagous to put /etc on its own partition (as well as /home)
just saw your comment: how big a partition should /etc have? and how advantageous?
- it just stores config stuff (like for X11, apt, samba sshd etc.).  So, if needing a reinstall - you don't need to reconfig all of that stuff.  Mine is 16 MB right now, I partitioned it for 200 MB.
gotcha, sounds like a good idea :)
- i mean /etc has about 16 MB of data.  It is pretty much all text files.
I would assume you aren't dual booting?
- it is a little more difficult to set up initially - but, I think it pays off in the end.
and how big is your /swap partition? (and that's it for my questions for now, I believe) :)
oh, one more: what tool do you use to partition?
- 1 GB - good rule of thumb is 1.5 x Physical ram.
- I use gparted
- yup.  2 of my machines are windowless.  It's just a shame that I need DirectX to shoot people when I'm in the mood :)
indeed
- good luck with it - see you in a few
do you use gparted from a live cd?
- ya - I always have a copy of Knoppix kicking around.
- but, it is on the live CD install.
- just select the "Manually edit partition table"
- has saved my bacon on numerous occasion.  ALthough - you can mount your physical drive from the Ubuntu install cd and run gparted
